project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
We saw this on JAC. The existing green hopper fields had the old searcher key and thus had no searchers associated with them.

I think so that you don't force the users to do this manual upgrade we should put the name of the searcher back to what it was.
fields.summary: In the latest build of green hopper, beta 3 you have renamed your custom field searcher (appended a ga to the end), this means we need to manually choose the searcher again

fields.description: We have a requirement for viewing the Linked Issues in the Task Board - Outline View. As of now there is a bar of Parent issue and the sub tasks are listed in below it. We need that instead of Sub tasks pre-configured linked issues are listed.
fields.summary: Link Association in Task Board - Outline View

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
When I created my Version I filled-in the description.  

However, after you select the Version Name, in the TASK-BOARD pull-down, the Version Description is not display. Please display the version description on the TASK-BOARD screen.
fields.summary: Add "version description" on the TASK-BOARD screen.

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description: Currently, we do not allow users to download the source of the GreenHopper plugin.  This issue should be held open to keep track of requests for the source.
fields.summary: Provide access to GreenHopper source code

fields.description: When releasing a number of charts are saved for future reference, it would be good to also save the data in a CSV. The CSV is available prior to release and should be available once released as well.
fields.summary: Save CSV of Hour Burndown Chart when releasing.

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
I found this quote in an issue:
bq. If you create issues in a project that is allowed to use GReenHopper then your subs will take the same FixVersions and components as the parent.
We would like this behavior to be an option. For instance, we have main tasks that span many iterations.  The subtasks are iteration specific and *should not inherit* from the parent.
fields.summary: Inheriting fix versions on subtask create needs to be optional

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
When "middle clicking" or selecting to "Open Link in New Tab" the existing page opens in a new tab, not the link that was selected. 

For example, "middle click" on an issue on the Task Board and it will open the Task Board in a new tab, when in actual fact I expect it to open the JIRA issue in a new tab.
fields.summary: Open Link in New Tab opens same page, not the link

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Click on "New Card" then select an issue type. Start entering data and then change the issue type. Data will be lost.

Two suggestions:
- Either fix the issue type that it can not be changed once selected, or
- *preferably* allow the Issue Type to be changed on the New Card dialogue without losing data.
fields.summary: Changing Issue Type in New Card dialogue loses data

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Undertake a thorough review of the:

- Configuration Screens: "Save & Revert?", Remove Auto Save, 
- List/Card/Summary View layout
fields.summary: UI Review

fields.description:
Morning chaps,

This is not so much a support issue as an "FYI" which may come in useful to both you and your customers who are attempting a similar migration to ourselves.

Background:

We currently are running our "Live" JIRA instance with a MySQL backend. Most of our enterprise apps. use Oracle for the DB and so we have been working on a project to migrate JIRA data to Oracle. We carried out the requisite steps (XML export, repoint database at Oracle, XML import) and it seemed to work quite nicely - until, that is, we attempted to access GreenHopper. Clicking the GreenHopper link was incredibly slow - it took over 3 minutes from clicking the link to get to the Planning Board.

We carried out some investigation and determined that this delay was caused by Oracle executing a particular query over 40 times and each query was taking around 3 seconds to return. Actual query causing the problem:

SELECT ID, pkey, PROJECT, REPORTER, ASSIGNEE, issuetype, SUMMARY, DESCRIPTION, ENVIRONMENT, PRIORITY, RESOLUTION, issuestatus, CREATED, UPDATED, DUEDATE, VOTES, IMEORIGINALESTIMATE, TIMEESTIMATE, TIMESPENT, WORKFLOW_ID, SECURITY, FIXFOR, COMPONENT FROM jiraissue WHERE pkey IS NULL

Here's the analysis from our DBA:

"The slowdown on starting GreenHopper from the Oracle JIRA instance is being caused by a query that attempts to do an "IS NULL" comparison against the pkey column of the Jiraissue table (94k rows).

The problem with this is, Oracle is doing a full table scan for the query (and this is occurring multiple times ... presumably GreenHopper is executing the query for each project or something).

The full table scan is in turn causing cluster issues because each query has to ping the other node to ensure the blocks being referenced haven't changed.  Hence the huge amounts of IO we saw this morning.

So why a full table scan and not an index scan ? (which would be faster).

Essentially relational database design stipulates that a NULL means no value or "unknown" - thus Oracle doesn't record it in the index.

Nulls are never stored in an index, and database design principles always recommend using a real value to indicate "unknown" instead of an actual NULL.

I've applied a slight "hack" on to the index however to see if it will be a suitable work-around. 

Essentially I've recreated an index as a composite (with a constant arbitrary value as the second part of the key).  Essentially forcing the NULL to be included in the index.

This seems to have worked, but we should keep an eye on the GreenHopper over the next couple of days just to be sure.

If this works, I'd suggest applying the same change to the jiraissue table in the iplay jira instance.

It may also be worth raising this with Atlassian / GreenHopper .... The database behaviour between Oracle and MySQL is different in this respect."

Note that this issue is exacerbated by running Oracle in a clustered environment (as ours is) although it would still manifest itself in a stand-alone configuration. Can you cast an eye over this analysis and let us know if it makes sense to you, please?

Regards,

Alan Ferrier

fields.summary: I would like to be able to generate reports and charts that show velocity by sprint and remaining points

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
I have a release that has sorints associated with it and user stories being assigned to sprints.   As long as all user stories are assigned to a sprint and closed within the sprint the burndown numbers are correct.  If the story gets closed before getting assigned to a sprint the burn down chart by children does not see the issues and therefore the remaing is not decremented.   It would be nice to have the Parent called out as a "sprint" with its own bar on the chart, or some way to include this info.

I know all items should be in a sprint but it just does not happen all the time

Thanks Tom

*Workaround*

Drag the stories into one of the sprints. This will skew your data.

fields.description:
This is a copy of: http://www.greenpeppersoftware.com/jira/browse/GHS-1312

We using encoding iso-8859-1 in Jira to support norwegian characters in attachments.

"New card" in GreenHopper do not support this encoding. It looks like encoding is UTF-8, but Jira handles it as it is iso-8859-1. Is UTF-8 encoding hardcoded?

Se examples in sceenshots:
1. New card in GreenHopper
2. Create Issue in Jira

*Workaround*

Converted Jira to UTF-8.

fields.description:
If the Balsamic UI mockups plugin is installed but disabled Greenhopper still shows a link to add a UI Mockup, clicking on the link will return a 404 error. 

This is a problem on JIRA Studio where both plugins are installed by default, but the UI Mockups is disabled unless it is requested to be activated. 

We should check that the plugin is installed and enabled: 

{code:sql}select * from propertyentry pe join propertystring ps on pe.id=ps.id where property_key ='jira.plugin.state-.com.balsamiq.jira.plugins.mockups'
jira-> ;
  id   |   entity_name   | entity_id |                     property_key                     | propertytype |  id   | propertyvalue 
-------+-----------------+-----------+------------------------------------------------------+--------------+-------+---------------
 10131 | jira.properties |         1 | jira.plugin.state-.com.balsamiq.jira.plugins.mockups |            5 | 10131 | false
{code}

fields.description:
How to reproduce:
- create version "1.0"
- create version "1.1"
- create version "1.2"
- make "1.0" master version of "1.1" and "1.2"
- release version 1.1
- create issue 1, set fix version 1.1
- create issue 2, set fix version 1.2

If you switch to planning board and select version "1.0" display "all" issues. Click on "synchronize" it will only display issue 2 for synchronisation. I'd like to have all issues to be in sync.

fields.description:
This is probably a highly edge-case bug, but I will document it here and if you choose not to fix it I totally understand. I will be fixing the conditions that cause this situation to occur which should prevent this bug from happening in the first place.

Version 3.3 of GreenHopper does not suffer from this bug. When upgrading to version 3.8 of GreenHopper and when trying to access the tool via the "GreenHopper" menu bar I receive a NullPointerException as documented in the attached {{npe.log}}.

This occurs when a user who has issues assigned to him in a project that is activated for GreenHopper does not have an entry in the {{propertyentry}} table for their fullName and/or email.

Normally when performing the following query for username "myuser" you should see multiple entries (at a minimum 2) in the propertyentry table.

{{select * from propertyentry where ENTITY_NAME='OSUser' and ENTITY_ID = (select id from userbase where username='myuser');}}

My installation of Jira has recently adapted the jira "auto-registeration" plugin (http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAEXT/Jira+LDAP+user+auto-registration+on+login) to automatically provision users from ActiveDirectory upon login if their account does not already exist in Jira. It works great, but if the user's email address or display name are null in ActiveDirectory then these values do not get set but the user account is still created.

Because of this behavior we have maybe half a dozen accounts in our Jira installation missing these entries in the {{propertyentry} table and when GreenHopper runs into a user in this situation it blows up.
fields.summary: Missing propertyentry for user results in NPE when loading GreenHopper

fields.description:
JC,

We are getting a lot of users complaining about the performace of GH.  We are working on adding more memory and things of that nature but one suggestion to help the user experience as it relates to performance would be to allow the user to set the page values to the items of interest and then submit the page instead of submitting the page everytime the user navigates to the page.

For example:

I may have the planning board set to one set of values and when I navigate to the planning board I have to wait for the page to display.  If that is not what I want to see then I set the page to the items of interest and have to wait again.  Every time I navigate I have to wait for the page to query and display the results.  This results in a less than optimal user experience, and leads to a percieved performance problem.

This is really important

fields.description:
Hello

With the current version of GH it is possible to define non-working days. These apply globally to all assignees. Vacation and other individual leaves/non-working days remain as a major blind spot in the planning process. So it would be great if it would be possible to define non-working days at the assignee level.

*This is how the process works for me today:*
# For my sprint and release planning I use the planning board and contexts to show me the view of each team member
# Using the version view, I then assign tasks/subtasks from each team member (using context) to a version/sprint
# The "time remaining" figure on the version pannel (right side of screen) tells me how many estimate hours have been assigned to the team member for a given version/sprint
# I now have to manually check our sharepoint calendar to see/calculate how many days/hours the team member (assignee) is working during the period of the release/sprint (start/end date)
# With this calculation of available days for the team member, I cross check with the "time remaining" figure in GH
# If I have overloaded/underloaded the team member, I have to then adjust the number of tasks assigned

*The improvement I would like:*
* Enter general non-working days using the currently available feature in GH
* Enter non-wokring days per Assignee using the new feature
* Have GH calculate the available days pased on
** For Version, Component and Projecto verview view: Assignee/Group of current context (JIRA Filter or Custom Filter)
** For Assignee view: Calculated for each displayed assignee
* Signal overloaded team members with some form of graphical signaling

fields.description:
Hello

If you have a chart which covers a larger time scale, value labels become hard or impossible to read because there are so many points plotted in a small space (see attached screen shot). Suggestion: Never show more than X labels on a chart. You then would only label every Nth value, where N = Total Plot Points / X. This way you would have more space between the data labels and it would be easier to read.

*Workaround*

You can hide the labels via your User Preferences (second icon on the top)
This was intended for big charts where the labels shows up as a big fat black line
